_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 Accident release prevention and emergency response policies:
The AGA gas Inc. (AGA) facility located in Wayland, Michigan complies with all
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA)
regulations and National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) codes as well as all local, state and
federal regulations applicable to storage of Liquified propane gas.  If an emergency or release of
propane occurred the Leighton Township fire Department would be notified and respond to the
emergency.  AGA also has an emergency response team that can be called to respond to a leak.

2.0 Description of facility and regulated substance:
The AGA facility stores liquified propane gas in a 18,000 gallon steel above ground tank that is
filled to 85% of capacity.  The process includes the 18,000 gallon storage tank, piping, pump,
filling manifold, automatic emergency closure valves, fire monitor and cylinders of various sizes.

3.0 Worst case release scenario:  The worst case release scenario for the facility considers the
potential failure of one 18,000 gallon propane storage tank filled to 85% capacity (administrative
controls) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Utilizing a computer based RMP*COMP version
106 the methodology presented in USEPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis the distance to
the flammable endpoint (1 p.s.i. overpressure) was determined to be <0.3 miles.  The public
receptors affected under the worst case release scenario include commercial and one residential
property.  Approximately 4 persons are within the residential population affected.

4.0 Alternate release scenario:
The alternate release scenario considers the potential release of propane from a 100 pound
capacity storage cylinder leaking caused by a leaking cylinder valve resulting in a vapor cloud
explosion.  The release period was 60 minutes.  Utilizing RMP*COMP the distance to the
flammable end point was determined to be <0.1 miles and there is no commercial or resident

ial
population exposed.

5.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
The AGA facility complies with all EPA Risk Management Plan, OSHA Process Safety
Management and NFPA rules, regulations and codes.  Pre start up safety audits are conducted as
well as process hazard reviews are completed every five years and an audit completed every three
years.  Monthly inspections are also completed of the installation.

6.0 Five Year Accident History
Not applicable as this is a new facility.

7.0 Emergency Response Program:
In the event of an accidental release involving propane it is AGA's policy to immediately notify
the Leighton Township Fire Department who would respond to the emergency.  The facility has
an Emergency Action Plan which all facility employees have been trained on (annually) and they
have continuous access to the plan.

8.0 Planned changes to improve safety
Continuous audits and inspections of the facility and propane installation.
